results.headline: These Law Enforcers Will Stop at Nothing

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Gangster Squad

results.summary_short: “Gangster Squad” is a throwback to another time, with some character voices reminiscent of McGruff and Offissa Pupp thrown in.

results.headline: A Flip Side to the Attack on Fracking

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of FrackNation

results.summary_short: If your only exposure to hydraulic fracturing, or fracking — extracting natural gas from shale — has been “Gasland,” then “FrackNation” has a different perspective to offer.

results.headline: Raised by Political Activists in a Dictatorship’s Shadow

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Clandestine Childhood

results.summary_short: Benjamín Ávila’s film is a semiautobiographical story about a 12-year-old being raised in the late 1970s in Argentina by activists opposed to the ruling military junta.

results.headline: Bloggers Using the Internet to Spread Truth in China

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of High Tech, Low Life

results.summary_short: The documentary “High Tech, Low Life” follows two very different Chinese bloggers who try to report what the government-controlled press won’t.

results.headline: That House Grandma Left Her Is a Mess

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Texas Chainsaw 3D

results.summary_short: Alexandra Daddario, Scott Eastwood and Tremaine Neverson (a k a the singer Trey Songz) star in “Texas Chainsaw 3D,” the generic sixth installment of the horror series.

results.headline: The British Class Divide, on a Personal Scale

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of 56 Up

results.summary_short: This latest installment of Michael Apted’s “Up” documentary series finds the Britons he has been chronicling since they were 7 as barometers of the British class system.

results.headline: Personal Connection Amid Political Dissonance in the Middle East

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Une Bouteille à la mer

results.summary_short: A Palestinian and an Israeli forge a pen-pal connection in “A Bottle in the Gaza Sea.”

results.headline: Deep Down, He Wants to Help

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Promised Land

results.summary_short: Gus Van Sant’s “Promised Land,” starring Matt Damon as a drilling-rights salesman, is an earnest attempt to dramatize the central arguments about fracking and its impact.

results.headline: Remembrance of Passions (and Follies) Lost

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tabu

results.summary_short: In “Tabu” the Portuguese filmmaker Miguel Gomes tells two tales, that of a three women of different classes in contemporary Lisbon, and of the eldest one’s adventures in Africa during her youth.

results.headline: The Black, the White and the Angry

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Django Unchained

results.summary_short: “Django Unchained” is pulpy, digressive, jokey, giddily brutal and ferociously profane, but it is also a troubling and important movie about slavery and racism.

results.headline: A Happy Ending, Sort of, Comes With No Closure

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of West of Memphis

results.summary_short: “West of Memphis” follows the successful but prolonged legal battle to free the so-called West Memphis Three, who were released from prison last year under a plea bargain.

results.headline: ‘No Means No,’ and More From Wise Grandparents

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Parental Guidance

results.summary_short: When the grandparents step in to baby-sit for a few days, generational child-rearing styles clash, and smiles and tears and a lot of sentimentality ensue.

results.headline: The Wretched Lift Their Voices

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Les Misérables

results.summary_short: Amid the grime, power ballads and surging strings, there is a familiar, reassuring story of oppression, liberation and redemption.

results.headline: Playing With the Band When the Music Meant Everything

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Not Fade Away

results.summary_short: In “Not Fade Away,” David Chase has written and directed a portrait of what it meant to chase rock ’n’ roll dreams in the 1960s.

results.headline: Pushed and Pulled, a Doctor Wants a Way Out

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Barbara

results.summary_short: The lead character in “Barbara,” a doctor in 1980s East Germany, tries to adjust after being transferred from Berlin to a more remote location as a punishment.

results.headline: Might Makes Him Mr. Right

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Jack Reacher

results.summary_short: Tom Cruise is the familiar archetype title character in “Jack Reacher,” dispensing righteous violence and hard-boiled aphorisms.

results.headline: Happy Birthday, You Miserable Achievers

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of This Is 40

results.summary_short: A couple — with their nice jobs, nice house, nice daughters and nice income — bemoan their troubles in “This Is 40,” directed by Judd Apatow (and starring his own wife and daughters).

results.headline: Swept Away and Torn Apart in a Sea of Despair

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Impossible

results.summary_short: “The Impossible,” starring Naomi Watts and Ewan McGregor, can be described as a horror film, with nature as the villain.

results.headline: Thrill-Seeking Beats Take the Scenic Route

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of On the Road

results.summary_short: The Brazilian director Walter Salles wrestles with Jack Kerouac’s 1957 novel, “On the Road,” which inspired countless stoned hippie odysseys to Haight-Ashbury and beyond.

results.headline: Almost Like Being in Vegas

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cirque Du Soleil: Worlds Away

results.summary_short: Andrew Adamson directs a 3-D film with the easy-to-recognize, hard-to-describe Cirque du Soleil blend of athletic bravura, surreal wit and abstract, family-friendly eroticism.
